entry.title: AviaSim Designs Releases Conington Aerodrome for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. AviaSim Designs recently released their rendition of Conington Aerodrome / Peterborough Business Airport (EGSF) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. This privately owned airfield is 13 kilometers south of Peterborough in the English county of Cambridgeshire. Originally built as RAF Glatton in 1942-1943 by the 809th United States Army Corps of Engineers to house B-17 bombers of the 457th Bomb Group, it was passed to the Royal Air Force after the end of the war. A year later, it was mothballed, and most of the structure vanished over the following years, leaving just a hangar and a water tower. The airfield saw some use in the 1960s from two local companies, which used its runway and hangar to store their aircraft. A ground engineer provided basic maintenance facilities.Â Aerolease Ltd. currently operates it, and aviation fuel is available on-site. Hangarage and parking must be arranged beforehand. The current layout consists of two runways: runway 16/34, which isnât AIP or NAPS listed, is approximately 800 meters long and in worse condition than the listed one (10/28), which is slightly longer at 987 meters. The scenery features an up-to-date layout, custom aerial imagery, 4K PBR textures, custom ground poly, sloped runway profile, dynamic lighting, and more. â Itâs available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $10.86, requiring at least 335.30 MB of free hard disk space to install. entry.title: ShortFinal Design Releases San Jose International Airport for X-Plane 12

The airport serves Santa Clara Valley and the San Francisco Bay Area and has a yearly average of 12 million passengers. â Officially opened in 1939, its first proper runway was only built six years later on land leased by test pilot James M. Nissen and his partners. A hangar and an office building for a flight school were also built.Â The city took over shortly after, with James Nissen becoming the airport's first manager, considerably instrumental in its infrastructural development. â The increased demand for air travel in the 1960s led to constructing the first proper terminal building, which later became Terminal C. Throughout the late 20th and early 21st centuries, SJC witnessed continued growth. Terminal A opened in 1990, followed by the city council's approval of a new master plan for long-term expansion in 1997. entry.title: Microsoft Releases Sim Update 15 for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Microsoft has recently released the long-awaited Sim Update 5 for Microsoft Flight Simulator after a series of delays and controversies. The new update brings performance improvements, faster loading times, airport fixes, and the A320neo V2 by iniBuilds. â Focusing on performance gains and stability, Sim Update 15 claims to bring significant framerate gains where it was otherwise low, fewer stutters, especially on long sessions, and substantially faster loading times. The performance figures on glass cockpit heavy airplanes, such as the 747, have also been greatly improved thanks to their work optimizing the Coherent/JS tech stack. On the stability front, Microsoft has devised a way to stop the console version from crashing when it runs out of memory by detecting the issue before it happens and temporarily reallocating the memory, causing a brief loss of detail quality while preventing a hard crash. â The physics front has also seen changes, with a new high-accuracy physics system to enable vibrations and micro-movements, a more accurate ground contact model, and an optional soft ground collision model for tires and flexible gears.Â â The A320neo V2 by iniBuilds is now available, featuring a high-quality 3D model, improved system fidelity, high-resolution textures, and a high-detail cabin for PC users. Microsoft has shared a video introducing us to the brand-new aircraft: â The complete changelog follows below: â The update is available right now on all compatible platforms. entry.title: Final Approach Design Studios Releases Sylhet Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Final Approach Design Studios recently released their version of Sylhet Airport (VGSY) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. Officially known as Osmani International Airport, the airport serves the Bangladeshi city of Sylhet. The airport is the third busiest in the country and is located around 5 miles from the city centre. It serves an average of just under 650.000 passengers annually. Osmani International Airport was built during the period of 1944-1945. It was constructed during World War II with the purpose of controlling Japanese aggression from Burma. Initially opened as Sylhet Civil Airport, it started as a domestic airport. In 1986, a terminal building, navigational aids, new runway pavement, taxiways, and aprons were constructed. The airport saw its first international flight in 2002 and has since undergone further expansion and upgrades. Today, the airport is operated by airlines such as Biman Bangladesh Airlines and Novoair, offering flights to destinations such as Dhaka, London, and Dubai. The recently released version of Sylhet Airport features 4K PBR textures, highly detailed ground poly, detailed 3D buildings, ground service equipment, animated jetways, terminal interiors, and more. The add-on requires a total of 1.40GB of storage space and is available on iniBuilds for roughly $14.99. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold!

entry.title: ST Simulations Announces Maastricht-Aachen Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. ST Simulations has recently announced the development and imminent release of Maastricht-Aachen Airport (EHBK) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. The airport serves Maastricht, in the Netherlands, and Aachen, in Germany, with a yearly average of 97.000 passengers. It was built by the Allies as a temporary airfield during World War 2, later transferred to the Dutch government and named Beek Airfield. It saw lots of traffic during its initial months because most roads in the country had been bombed and/or heavily damaged. As the repairs progressed, the traffic figures died down. The first semi-permanent terminal was built in 1947, followed by runway paving work in 1949 and 1950. Further expansion work was carried on from 1951 and beyond after an agreement between the airport and the Dutch Air Force. The airport underwent expansion work in the early 1970s to handle bigger aircraft, which included runway lengthening, taxiway widening, and apron enlargement. A decade later, a new passenger terminal was built, replacing the old one from the 40s. Corendon Dutch Airlines, Pegasus Airlines, and Ryanair serve it. â The scenery will feature an accurate rendition of the airport, with an up-to-date ground layout, custom ground textures, custom taxiway signage, custom objects, PBR texturing, aÂ realistic runway profile, and more. Refer to theirÂ websiteÂ for further information. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â â

entry.title: Cloudsurf Asia Releases Clark International Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Cloudsurf Asia has recently released its version of Clark International Airport (RPLC) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. The airport is located 50 miles northwest of Manila and serves both the Central Luzon and Northern Luzon regions, welcoming just under 1.9 million passengers annually. In 1902, after the United States Cavalry established Fort Stotsenberg, part of it was converted into an airfield, which was later renamed Clark Air Field in 1919. In 1991, the Philippine government took over Clark Air Field, and it wasn't until 1996 that the airport opened for commercial operations. Over the years, the airport has undergone various expansions and developments. Today, the airport features an 889.000 square feet terminal, opened in 2022, and one runway after the former second runway was decommissioned due to its proximity to the other one. The airport handles both passenger and cargo operations and serves airlines such as Cebu Pacific, Sunlight Air, Emirates, and Qatar, offering a variety of destinations such as Cebu, Dubai, and more. The airport sees around 5.500 aircraft movements annually. The newly released version of Clark International Airport for MSFS includes many features such as fully custom objects, terminal interior, PBR textures, custom animated jetways, and much more. The add-on requires a total of 1.63 GB of storage space and is now available on Orbx for approximately $23.82. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold!

entry.title: New Takeoff and Landing Calculations Feature in Simbrief
entry.summary: Sim: OTHER. SimBrief has recently been updated to include takeoff and landing calculations in the flight planning application. entry.title: 29Palms Releases Santorini Airport & Island for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. 29Palms has just released its version of Santorini Airport (LGSR) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. The scenery package includes a highly realistic version of Santorini Airport, as well as the entire island of Santorini. The airport welcomes around 2.7 million passengers to the Greek island annually. The airport was first used in 1972 for military purposes and began commercial operations in the early 1980s. In 2015, a joint venture of Fraport AG/Copelouzos Group and the state privatisation fund took over the airport, with plans to operate it for 40 years. A major renovation in 2021 included numerous upgrades and refurbishments. Currently, the airport offers year-round flights to Athens and Thessaloniki, with seasonal operations to destinations such as Oslo, London, and Paris. Airlines like Aegean Airlines, Jet2.com, and Ryanair ensure that Santorini receives around 2.7 million passengers and 24.000 aircraft movements annually. The new scenery package by 29Palms includes custom buildings, interior, updated layout, and dynamic lights for the airport, as well as mesh terrain in 3m/pixel resolution, vegetation, villages, ports, points of interest, animations, and AI vessel traffic for the island. The airport was built in the early 1940s on a 600-acre piece of land near Cherokee Hill, with three 3600-foot runways covering all possible wind options. The US Army Air Corps soon took it over as a bomber and training base for B-24 bombers and fighter aircraft. It was temporarily named Chatham Airfield, and its infrastructure greatly improved during that short period. Post WW2, it was turned over to the Georgia Air National Guard and renamed Travis Field after a late local Brigadier General, victim of a fatal B-29 accident in California. â â A new airline terminal was built in 1958, and runway extension work followed in 1962, preparing the airport for the jet age. entry.title: Gate15Scenery Releases Rishiri Airport V2 for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Gate15Scenery has recently released the second version of its Rishiri Airport (RJER) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. The airport serves the entirety of Rishiri Island in Hokkaido Prefecture and has a yearly average of 38.000 passengers. The airport was built in the late 1960s when air travel was gaining momentum in Japan, and connecting remote islands became a priority. Initially, the airport served a limited number of flights, primarily connecting Rishiri to the nearby Wakkanai Airport on the mainland. However, its presence proved crucial in boosting tourism and facilitating the transportation of goods and services. The airport also became a vital link for emergency medical services, ensuring timely access to specialized care for the island's residents. Over the years, Rishiri Airport has witnessed steady growth. The runway was extended in 1990 to accommodate larger aircraft, allowing for more direct flights and increased passenger capacity. Today, the airport serves several domestic destinations, including Sapporo and Tokyo, making travel to and from the island more convenient. Beyond its role in transportation, Rishiri Airport has become a symbol of the island's connection to the broader world. It serves as a gateway for visitors to experience the island's natural beauty, from the majestic Mount Rishiri to its diverse marine life. It's currently only served by ANA Wings and Hokkaido Air System, with flights to Sapporo (Chitose and Okadama). The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom ground textures, a terminal interior, an up-to-date ground layout, and more. Owners of the previous version are eligible for a free upgrade. It's available on SimMarket for roughly $14.38, requiring at least 298.89 MB of free hard disk space to install.
